Greetings I am julAi! How can I help you with your college questions?

patterns: List of faculty in Computer Science
Who teaches in the CS department?
Who are the teachers in Computer Science?
responses: The College of Computer Science has a team of dedicated faculty members. Some key professors include Sir Eleaczar Arma, Sir Michael Cruz, Sir Honorato Altar, and Sir Francis Claro Ahmed. Would you like more details about a specific professor?

Our faculty includes outstanding educators such as Sir Eleaczar Arma, Sir Michael Cruz, Sir Honorato Altar, and Sir Francis Claro Ahmed. Let me know if you'd like their contact information or office hours.
The CS department faculty consists of respected teachers like Sir Eleaczar Arma, Sir Michael Cruz, Sir Honorato Altar, and Sir Francis Claro Ahmed. Need any specific information about them?

patterns: Where is the Computer Science building?
How to find the CS building?
responses: The Computer Science building, known as the New Building, is located near the College of Engineering and the College of Criminology. It's easy to spot once you're in that area.
You'll find the CS department in the New Building, situated between the College of Engineering and the College of Criminology. Let me know if you need detailed directions.

CS classes are primarily held in the New Building, conveniently located close to both the College of Engineering and the College of Criminology. Would you like help navigating there from your current location?

patterns: What courses do first years take?
Courses for first year CS students
What will I study in my first year?
responses: First-year students typically take: Introduction to Programming, Discrete Mathematics, Computer Systems Fundamentals, and a general education course. You'll also have a Freshman Seminar in CS.
The freshman curriculum includes: CS 101 (Programming Basics), CS 110 (Computational Thinking), MATH 150 (Discrete Structures), and a university writing requirement.
In your first year, you'll build foundations with: Programming I, Digital Logic Design, Calculus for CS, and an elective. Would you like the course descriptions?

patterns: What courses do second years take?
Courses for second year CS students
What will I study in my second year?
responses: Second-year students typically take: Data Structures, Computer Architecture, Algorithms, and Probability for Computer Science. You'll also begin your specialization tracks.
The sophomore curriculum includes: CS 201 (Advanced Programming), CS 210 (Systems Programming), CS 220 (Theory of Computation), and your first track elective course.
In your second year, you'll dive deeper with: Object-Oriented Design, Operating Systems, Linear Algebra for CS, and your choice of specialization courses. Need details about any of these?
We offer five specializations: 1) Artificial Intelligence, 2) Cybersecurity, 3) Data Science, 4) Software Engineering, and 5) Computer Systems. You'll choose at the end of your second year.
Our concentration areas include: Game Development, Cloud Computing, Bioinformatics, Human-Computer Interaction, and Network Systems. Would you like details about any specific track?
You can specialize in: Machine Learning, Database Systems, Computer Graphics, or Embedded Systems. Each has unique course requirements and career paths.

patterns: Where can I work on projects?
responses: There are many computer labs located in the New Building, specifically ITlab1 to ITlab6. Each lab is equipped with plenty of computers for student use.
You can find several labs in the New Building, from ITlab1 to ITlab6, all offering numerous computers for your projects and coursework.
The New Building houses ITlab1 to ITlab6, providing many computers for students to work on. Feel free to visit any available lab during operating hours.

patterns: What jobs can I get with CS degree?
responses: Our graduates work at top tech companies like Google, Microsoft, and Amazon, as well as in finance, healthcare, and government sectors. Common roles include software engineer, data analyst, and systems architect.
With a CS degree, you can pursue careers in: app development, cybersecurity analysis, machine learning engineering, database administration, or game design. Our career center has more details.
Recent graduates have secured positions at Facebook, NASA, local startups, and research institutions. We also have strong internship pipelines with tech companies in the area.

patterns: How can I get involved in research?
How to join a research project?
responses: Many professors take on undergraduate researchers. Check our department website for open positions, or talk to your professors after class about their ongoing projects.
We offer the CS Research Scholars program where students can work 10 hours/week on faculty projects. Applications open each semester. There are also summer research fellowships available.
First-years can start with the Introduction to Research seminar (CS 198). Many students present at our annual Undergraduate Research Symposium in their second year.

patterns: How to meet other CS students?
responses: Two of the most common clubs are the Linux Users Group Club and the Chess Club. If you have a new idea, you're also welcome to create your own club!
Students often join the Linux Users Group Club and the Chess Club. You're free to start a new club if you want to bring students together around a shared interest.
The Linux Users Group Club and the Chess Club are popular among CS students, but you can also propose and create your own club if you have something new in mind.

patterns: How do I contact my advisor?
responses: First-year students are assigned a faculty advisor during orientation. You can schedule appointments through the Student Portal. Drop-in advising is available Tuesdays 1-3pm in the CS office.
Advising for course registration happens weeks 10-12 each semester. Your advisor's contact information is in your student profile. They can help with course selection and career planning.

patterns: What do I need to graduate?
How many credits for CS major?
What's needed for BS in CS?
responses: The BS in CS requires 120 credits: 60 in major courses (including capstone), 30 in math/science, and 30 in general education. You'll need to complete a specialization track and maintain a 2.5 GPA in major courses.
Degree requirements include: 8 core CS courses, 5 track electives, 2 advanced math courses, the senior project, and university writing requirements. Your advisor can provide a personalized checklist.
You can track your progress in the Student Portal's Degree Audit system. It shows completed requirements and what's remaining for your CS degree.
